data.text:
Notes for REGINALD JOHN MARTIN:

Notes of Robert Martin, Whitby Ontario (Ref# 1302):

Grave marker shows date of birth as 1885 as it was only after I had the marder placed that I discovered that the date on the birth gegistration was the date the birth was registered and when I got the birth certificate I found the date of birth 1884 and the date of registration as March 30, 1885.

Reginald worked on the family farm and for farmers in the area.Sometime before 1905 he went West to farm.He went first to the Dauphin area of Manitoba.He then went to the Invermay area of Saskatchewan. When he applied for a patent for the farm he states he obtained the homestead in July 1906, built his house in May 1909 and commenced actual residence in Feb. 1908.He lists the times he was absent from the homestead and says when absent he was farming near Dauphin.He came home for a visit in the winter of 1912-13.On his return to the west he was to be married in the spring.Soon after his return to the west he was travelling from Sheho to Invermay in April.While crossing a river in flood near Sheho, the bridge either collpased or the horses were swept away off the bridge. One horse was killed and when Reg went to check on the other it reared up and kicked him in the head leaving an imprint. He either died instantly or very shortly after.

Notes for MALCOLM ROBERT MARTIN:

He served in the 136 battalion in WW1. He had prieviously run the family farm on the 6th Line but sold it in 1921 because it was too small to be economical.He then went to Toronto to work in the Goodyear.In 1927 he bought a farm near at Long Sault near Tyrone. May Johns, his mother, and May's daughter, Doris, lived with him.In 1941 because of severe asthma he left the farm to Doris and her husband and moved back to the Goodyear Plant in Toronto living with his cousin, Duncan McMillan, on Quebec Ave.In 1951 because of severe asthma he was forced to move to Arizona. He had had asthma for years but it gradually got more severe and his doctor told him if he wanted to live, he would have to move to Arizona.He returned to the Newcastle area each year for a family visit. He was a quite, kind man in build the build of his father but with short legs.He had been a noted ballplayer in Kendal in his youth and remained a ball fan often visiting Maple Leaf Stadium to watch a AAA League ballgame
